what: Keep track of dates and medications through pregnancy and fertility treatment
title: Keep track of dates and medications through pregnancy and fertility treatment
text: work--progress R package tracking dates medications pregnancy fertility treatment. early stages development. Update 2023-03-25: long hiatus, now actively returning work project. R code getting major overhaul. package best-practices, like documentation, tests, vignettes, pkgdown website etc, also forthcoming. ’ll hex sticker !

title: Calculate due date — calculate_due_date
text: start_date Start date start_type Start type cycle Cycle length

title: Calculate due date — calculate_due_date
code: my_start_date <- as.Date("2023-01-31") calculate_due_date(my_start_date) #> ℹ Estimated due date: Tuesday, November 07, 2023 #> ℹ Estimated birth period begins: October 17, 2023 (37 weeks) #> ℹ Estimated birth period ends: November 21, 2023 (42 weeks) due_date <- calculate_due_date(my_start_date, "conception") #> ℹ Estimated due date: Tuesday, October 24, 2023 #> ℹ Estimated birth period begins: October 03, 2023 (37 weeks) #> ℹ Estimated birth period ends: November 07, 2023 (42 weeks) due_date #> [1] "2023-10-24" class(due_date) #> [1] "Date"

title: An example medications table — medications
text: data frame example medications might used fertility treatment/first trimester. example data frame might used meds argument meds_remaining().

title: An example medications table — medications
text: data frame 14 rows 5 columns: medication Name medication format Format medication quantity Number taken per day start_date Date start taking medication stop_date Final date medication taken. See details.

title: An example medications table — medications
text: Note medication (prednisolone example) several rows, first quantity taken per day changes, needs taken non-consecutive days.

title: An example medications table — medications
code: medications #> # A tibble: 14 × 5 #>    medication   format    quantity start_date stop_date  #>    <chr>        <chr>        <dbl> <date>     <date>     #>  1 progynova    pills            3 2023-04-21 2023-04-30 #>  2 LDA          pills            1 2023-04-21 2023-05-07 #>  3 prednisolone pills            2 2023-04-26 2023-05-07 #>  4 progynova    pills            6 2023-05-01 2023-07-11 #>  5 cyclogest    pessary          2 2023-05-03 2023-07-11 #>  6 lubion       injection        1 2023-05-03 2023-07-11 #>  7 clexane      injection        1 2023-05-08 2023-09-05 #>  8 prednisolone pills            4 2023-05-08 2023-07-11 #>  9 prednisolone pills            3 2023-07-12 2023-07-14 #> 10 prednisolone pills            2 2023-07-15 2023-07-17 #> 11 prednisolone pills            1 2023-07-18 2023-07-20 #> 12 prednisolone pills            1 2023-07-22 2023-07-22 #> 13 prednisolone pills            1 2023-07-24 2023-07-24 #> 14 prednisolone pills            1 2023-07-26 2023-07-26

title: Title — meds_remaining
code: meds_remaining(   on_date = Sys.Date(),   meds = NULL,   group = c("medication", "format") )

title: Title — meds_remaining
text: on_date date meds meds group group

title: Title — meds_remaining
text: prints console, returns data frame invisibly

title: Title — meds_remaining
code: meds_remaining(on_date = as.Date("2023-04-30"), meds = medications) #> # A tibble: 6 × 2 #>   medication   quantity_remaining #>   <chr>                     <int> #> 1 LDA                           8 #> 2 clexane                     121 #> 3 cyclogest                   140 #> 4 lubion                       70 #> 5 prednisolone                297 #> 6 progynova                   435
